Topic.Title: Once again I wil ask about volume of trading..

Message.Msg: One reason: the financials are still uncertain and the derivatives exposure BAC maintains is rather frightening. Nobody can accurately value this company. If you are already in it, just let it consolidate at this price. Sell half of your position and buy oversold undervalued companies like Pandora (P) and Youku (YOKU). The only way to make money in this market is to ignore the headlines which are often negative, often wrong and try to catch the bottom bounce on the losers which eventually reverse, at least for the short-term. Both companies are actually good companies under pressure for different reasons, but they don't do derivatives and are easy to value.

Message.Title: Wan Hung Lo to travel with the Prez to Detroit today!
Message.Msg: President Obama travels to Detroit today to talk about the need for increased taxes on top earners to finance federal spending, and is using an announcement of a $100 million investment from German auto giant Daimler to illustrate that his economic prescription is working. Obama is not likely to discuss another big business story of the day â the sale of the assets of battery maker A123 to a Chinese competitor. A123 spent at least $132 million of its $249 million stimulus package grant to build two Detroit-area factories, including one in Livonia, right next door to Redford Township, where Obama is speaking today. Assuming a bankruptcy judge and the Obama Treasury Department approve of the sale of A123âs assets to Wanxiang Group, the Chinese battery maker would immediately become the dominant force in the industry. So for $256.6 million, the Chinese firm would get all that the stimulus package purchased plus the companyâs existing operations in Massachusetts and Missouri and have the chance to pare down the company to profitability without the overhead of A123âs debt. A very good deal to be sure, but not one that American firms were willing to take on. As the president has often said, China and its economic central planners are betting very big on the battery business â for cars, for the electric grid, etc. And with A123, they get to take advantage of not only their own government subsidies, but those provided by American taxpayers. An additional irony: Whatever share of the original $249 million stimulus grant that the Treasury borrowed from China will still have to be paid back. The boys in Beijing must be having a happy Monday. Obama gave A123 lots of subsidy money to expand to compete with subsidized Chinese firms and the subsidized Chinese firms win anyway.

Message.Title: Food stamp use reaches another high in September: 47.7 million
Message.Msg: Participation in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, or food stamps, reached another high in September, according to new data released by the United Stated Department of Agriculture. The most recent data on SNAP participation were released Friday, and showed that 47,710,324 people were enrolled in the program in September, an increase of 607,559 from the 47,102,765 enrolled in August. Message.Title: BofA finely did the right thing
Message.Msg: I was in a Countrywide sub-prime loan after listening to a bad broker and not reading the 100 page loan docs. I had no idea what negative amortization was and it was masked in the loan docs. After purchasing Countrywide, B of A put us in a 5 year fixed convertible variable loan that was set to expire this coming summer. It was a 5 7/8 interest only loan and I have never missed a mortgage payment . After pleading and begging with them for a modify to a lower interest long term loan, they announced a government settlement this past February. After waiting 10 months they finally put us in a long term (30 year) fixed loan at 4% interest that includes principle. It was my fault for signing a loan without a lawyer, but at least I wonât have to worry about the loan resetting next year and the terms were good enough that I am paying it down to 15 year loan by applying extra principle. I am still way underwater, but at least I have a chance now to catch up. By the way, the modify docs were about 5 pages long, and I sent them to a lawyer before signing them. Cost me $100, but was well worth it.

Topic.Title: Entitlements

Message.Msg: Right you are! You understand it correctly. Not like my college professors who said it is not an insurance policy at all but a pay as you go system of current workers funding current retirees - not current workers "paying premiums" to cover their own retirement - but that future workers will fund your retirement. What do professors know anyway? If you believe the "professors" then you believe that your children and grandchildren will pay for your benefits. No, no, the professors are wrong and you are right - it is an insurance policy for which a person can pay a relatively small premium and collect a huge benefit! The difference is paid by "insurance" not by taxpayers! You know exactly what you are talking about!!!

Message.Title: Rich Gain as Companies Seek to Beat Obama Tax Increases
Message.Msg: The wealthy look set to enjoy a windfall in the closing weeks of the year as companies push money out the door to beat the higher tax rates advocated by President Barack Obama. More than 150 companies, from Costco Wholesale Corp. to Las Vegas Sands Corp. (LVS), have declared special dividends totaling about $20 billion this quarter to avoid anticipated tax increases in 2013, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. Others, including law and private-equity firms, probably will pay bonuses, partnership distributions and commissions early for tax reasons, according to Lou Crandall, chief economist at Wrightson ICAP LLC in Jersey City, New Jersey. âWeâre going to have a big jump in household income in the fourth quarterâ said Crandall, whose company is a subsidiary of ICAP Plc, the worldâs largest broker of transactions between banks. âItâs going to be in excess of $50 billion.â

Topic.Title: Entitlements

Message.Msg: You are right! My college professors were wrong! There, I said it. It is not a pay as you go plan as the professors say with current workers funding current retirees. It is not a savings plan where you get out only what you pay in. It is an insurance policy where you get back more than you pay in and the difference comes from "insurance" not from future workers! It is that easy. For life insurance, you are right, that is a perfectly good analogy. Forget the professors who say it is not. Idiots. My professors incorrectly described it this way... a lot of people pay in and few die and collect the benefit. I am trying to remember what they call it.... oh, yeah, the law of large numbers. It takes a large number of people to fund the benefits of a few. Silly concept. You are completely correct. Your simple understanding of a simple concept is completely simpleton! You are also correct in saying that life insurance and disability insurance are the same. Forget what insurance agents say about it being different coverages, and if it comes in one package then it is two separate policies bundled together. What do insurance agents know about insurance anyway? Fake pretend profession is you ask me. I dont really care as long as I get MY benefits. Facts are just confusing anyway.

Topic.Title: Rich Gain as Companies Seek to Beat Obama Tax Increases

Message.Msg: So do you mean to imply that tax policy DOES influence behavior??? That is not what my mentors on MSNBC say so how can it be true? Perhaps you can explain something else to me. The guy who runs Costco, he supported Obama yes? He supported higher taxes on the rich yes? So then why is he paying a special dividend in 2012 to avoid the higher taxes in 2013? And why is he borrowing the money to pay for it? Does he get tax reductions in 2013 and beyond for the interest Costco will pay on the borrowed money? Maybe my math is off but I calculate that as a big tax avoidance from some who supported Obama's higher taxes. The only reason I care about it is that if somebody else gets a tax savings then that is less money to the government to pay MY benefits!!! Dangit!

Topic.Title: Entitlements

Message.Msg: perhaps the business professors you knew had their chairs funded by insurance companies? I do consider social security a form of life insurance. I started paying into the system at age 16 and I have paid 40+ yrs. to date. I never complained about those taxes-ever. My only complaint of the system is the expansion to give benefits to attention deceicit syndrome people, ssi,etc. to undeserving. Without this social insurance many of our fellow citizens would suffer, and suffer greatly. Many people do not have the skills to save for retirement. Thanks

Topic.Title: Entitlements

Message.Msg: Correct! It was LBJ in 1967 who started the rape of the SS trust fund. If he left it alone, the trust fund would be solvent for 347 years! Congress found some new money to spend. They took the money from the trust fund & put it in the general fund. Then they spent it while leaving IOUs. Been doing so for all these years & now Congress wants more money to squander for research on rectal temperatures of pregnant sparrows. The public sure is uninformed!

Topic.Title: Entitlements

Message.Msg: You are right too! My professors who say it is not insurance are wrong! And my insurance agent who says that life and disability insurance are two separate coverages are wrong too even if the benefits come bundled. It IS that simple. You are simple understanding of a simple concept is completely simpleton! My stupid professors handed me some silly story about the law of large numbers being involved in insurance where a large number of people pay premiums for a relatively small number of people to collect benefits or else the economics are unworkable. Silly concept. My professors must be biased republicans when they say that social security does not remotely fit the definition of insurance. Uneducated fools. Everybody knows that with insurance like you say social security is, everybody can pay in a little and everybody can collect a lot. That is the magic of insurance! Facts are just confusing anyway so dont let facts get in the way of your argument.

Topic.Title: BREAKING NEWS !!! Obama joined the Chicago Bulls !!!!

Message.Msg: We thinks you are a bunch of BULL!

Topic.Title: Entitlements

Message.Msg: I am well aware of insurance agents selling different policies. But think of it this way also. Those insurance companies pay agents very well, hire staff, charge rates,etc. and expect to make a lot of money and only charge you a pittance. How is that possible? They know the odds. And agents cherry pick their customers. Try buying disability without a thorough physical,etc. Can you say:denied?...however with s.s. their is no denial for coverage however there might be to receive the benefits. i am very happy s.s is federally run and administered. Their overhead and costs is 3%, whereas private sectors average 22%.

Topic.Title: Entitlements

Message.Msg: I doubt the business professor who taught from the National Association of Insurance Commissioners insurance accounting texbooks were influenced by the insurance industry. The NAIC regulates insurance companies and the NAIC wrote the text. Some of my professors had affilications with big CPA firms but most had no affiliation with any particular industry or company other than the university that employed them. You may reasonably think that social security is an insurance policy but it is not. Not in a legal sense or a mathematical sense. Insurance is based on the law of large numbers with many people paying in relatively small premiums to fund relatively few claims. Social security is indeed a pay as you go deal with some savings as margin in the trust fund. However, the unfunded liability to pay future benefits is in the tens of trillions. It is daunting to think about. It should have been set up as a savings account but unfortunately it was not. The US lost the opportunity when there were 30 people supporting each retiree. Then, we could have funded those retirees and also set aside savings for the 30 people retiring in the future. But we did not. Now it is something like 2.5 or 3 working people to fund each retiree and it will get worse when baby boomers like you and me hit the retirement roles. The math doesnt work out very well for our kids and grandkids. For the record, I started paying into the system at age 15 and now have 40 years into it too. And all that time I figured that I was paying for my grandparents and parents. As long as 20 or 30 years ago I thought the math would never work out and so I never have counted on SS to fund my retirement. Too bad for people who are counting on it, as you say, those who do not have the skills or wherewithall to save for retirement. That is why I think we need a means test where unfortunately some people who paid into it will get nothing out of it.

Topic.Title: Entitlements

Message.Msg: I agree that SS is good to be federally run and administered and they do it efficiently. But that does not change that it is a savings plan not insurance. Treating it as insurance when it is not funded as such is a losing proposition because nearly everybody collects, unlike insurance where a few collect. Otherwise, can you say "adverse selection?" That is where people who know they are bad risks seek out insurance only when they need it, the insurance company loses big time, raises premiums such that it becomes unafordable, and the system spirals downward. There have been real examples of this in mandated state insurance pools, called assigned risk pools, where the state dictates that anybody can be covered. One of the eastern states, Maine I believe, had this setup for workers comp insurance many years ago. The state wanted lobster fisherman, who are a very risky class, to have coverage so they could continue to operate. The state funded the pool with assessments on premiums in the free market, which caused free market premiums to go up. This put more businesses in the pool as the free market premiums on risky businesses increased, which further drove up premiums, and it continued on and on. Until one day when the assessements in the voluntary market to fund the in-voluntary market hit 600%. No kidding, it was 600%. Needless to say, the whole thing collapsed and the taxpayers then got stuck with the bill to bail it out. That is what happens when you mess with insurance and why SS is not insurance. It is an underfunded retirement savings plan.
